Award.AwardTitle: CC*IIE Networking Infrastructure: A High-Speed Scalable Research Core (HSSRC) at Washington State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Washington State University (WSU) is embracing scientific computing in research and education by implementing an overarching strategy to build capacity and capabilities in computational and data science and to better respond to the emerging, diverse, and rapidly evolving needs of the university's research community across several disciplines. To catalyze new multi-disciplinary research applications, accelerate data-driven scientific discovery, and enable transformative training activities, WSU is improving its high-speed network infrastructure by establishing a High Speed Scalable Research Core (HSSRC) to access wide-area science services and software-defined networking environments. The deployment of the HSSRC at WSU advances the state-of-knowledge within the participating scientific disciplines by enabling the data resulting from simulations and instruments to be analyzed more rapidly and efficiently. For example, access to the HSSRC allows materials scientists to apply predictive theory and simulation capabilities to efficiently explore the structure-properties-performance parameter space and design new materials with optimized and tailored properties; enables nuclear theorists to unlock the unsolved mysteries of our cosmos; allows energy grid engineers to analyze in real-time the large number of power grids scenarios; and opens the possibility for researchers in genomics, genetics, and bioinformatics to dissect the genomic basis of diversity and answer questions that range from disentangling the evolutionary history of organisms to linking genomic changes to phenotypic changes. Moreover, the deployment of a HSSRC at WSU enables the training of the next generation of scientific leaders with knowledge and experience in a broad range of modeling and simulation disciplines and "big data" science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Washington State University (WSU) is proud to announce the completion of the High Speed Scalable Research core on the Pullman campus. Funded by the NSF, this CC*IIE award has built a truly unique network core to satisfy the most demanding of research applications.

 While the grant funded both high speed routers at the network border and a pair of Brocade switches with 100Gbps upgrade capability,  the heart of this design is the deployment of six Software Defined Network (SDN) controlled Plexxi switches, each with 32 x 10 gigabits/second (Gbps) ports and 4 x 40Gbps ports. These six switches, one in each Main Communication Frame (MCF) are interconnected using Dense Wave Division Multiplexing (DWDM) over 12 strands of fiber forming a 240 Gbps ring. This topology allows WSU to add/drop 10Gbps Virtual LANs (VLANs) at any building with an available pair of single mode fiber. This layer 2 capability cuts laterally through the traditional hierarchical (core, distribution, edge) bypassing all layer 3 devices providing unprecedented low latencies and overall throughput.

Five buildings are connected to the HSSRC at 10Gbps with funding provided by the grant – Clark Hall, Electrical and Mechanical Engineering (E/ME), Institute of Shock Physics (ISP), Johnson Hall, and Heald Hall. The five facilities represent the main research buildings for WSU’s College of Agriculture, Human, and Natural Resource Sciences (CAHNRS), Voiland College of Engineering and Architecture (VCEA), and College of Arts and Sciences (CAS). Worthy of mention is the newest research building on campus, the PACCAR Environmental Research Technology Building, which was designed from the very beginning as an all-fiber building to be both cost effective and high performing. Gigabit Passive Optical Networking (GPON) is used to provide traditional instructional/administrative gigabit Ethernet services to each room over a single strand of single mode fiber. The building also has three of the SDN switches mentioned above, so where the researcher has the need for unrestricted performance, the same fiber optic infrastructure into their office can be simply cross connected to the HSSRC.

To date, there are two sets of infrastructure in Pullman connected to the HSSRC. The first is WSU’s latest High Performance Computing cluster, named Kamiak, located in the IT Building (ITB) datacenter. This condominium style computer is connected to the HSSRC via 2 x 40Gbps connections. A storage array, belonging to CAHNRS, is connected via 2 x 10Gbps. This storage is presented to the Kamiak and allows CAHNRS researchers to access the storage with actually better theoretical performance than they can in their local research labs.

With the HSSRC connection to E/ME, the Voiland College Engineering is making progress toward connecting their flagship HPC cluster, Aeolus, to the HSSRC in the spring of 2017. This will allow for a long-standing need to share computing workloads between Aeolus and Kamiak.

Another NSF grant (“MRI: Acquisition of an Integrated Data-Assisted Research and Training Scalable Storage System (IDARTs3) at Washington State University”), is building out the HSSRC connectivity to WSU’s health sciences campus in Spokane, Washington. When completed, a 10Gbps circuit will connect the HSSRC in Pullman to Spokane’s fledgling research computing and storage infrastructure.

Finally, an initiative is also underway to connect the HSSRC to the national research network fabric, addressing the very real concern about the HSSRC (and Science DMZ’s in general) being a “bridge to nowhere.” In partnership with the Pacific Northwest Gigapop (PNWGP), WSU has turned up 2 x 10Gbps links directly into the PNWGP’s PacWave switch in Seattle, Washington which itself is the premier onramp in the Northwest to the national research networking infrastructure with multiple 100Gbps connections. In partnership with Clemson, engineers and researchers are building a layer 2 path across country from WSU to Clemson.
